importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Millennium Seed Bank was opened in 2000 by The Prince of Wales (now The King), marking the beginning of its conservation mission.
The seed bank helped restore plant life after intense wildfires in Australia in 2019, providing a critical backup for native species.
This article was published on October 19, 2025, highlighting the ongoing relevance and expansion of the Millennium Seed Bank’s work after 25 years.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 25-year anniversary of the Millennium Seed Bank's establishment (2000–2025) underscores the long-term commitment to global plant conservation and ecological restoration.

keyTakeAways: The Millennium Seed Bank holds over 2.5 billion seeds from 40,000 wild plant species, representing a global effort to protect biodiversity.
The bank's original purpose was as a 'doomsday vault' to safeguard plant species from extinction, but today it is used to restore degraded ecosystems worldwide.
Restoration projects include chalk grasslands in the South Downs and tropical forests, demonstrating the bank’s global reach and adaptability.
Cate Blanchett, a Hollywood A-lister, has become a public ambassador for the project, enhancing its visibility and inspiring broader public engagement.
The project addresses climate change impacts such as rising wildfire frequency and habitat destruction, offering tangible solutions through ecological recovery.
The King (formerly Prince of Wales) has publicly emphasized the critical importance of plant conservation, linking it to broader environmental and extinction risks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Cate Blanchett, a celebrated Hollywood actress, has become a passionate ambassador for the Kew Gardens Millennium Seed Bank (MSB), which celebrates its 25th anniversary. The MSB, located at Wakehurst Botanic Garden in Sussex, houses over 2.5 billion seeds from 40,000 wild plant species and plays a vital role in both preserving biodiversity and restoring degraded habitats globally. Originally conceived as a 'doomsday vault' to protect plant species from extinction, the bank now actively supports ecological restoration projects such as those in the South Downs and post-wildfire recovery in Australia. The project has gained renewed relevance due to climate change, with rising wildfire intensity threatening native species like those in Australia. The King (formerly Prince of Wales) has publicly emphasized the urgency of plant conservation. Cate Blanchett, who visited the site and engaged in hands-on seed work, expresses deep admiration for the project and believes it represents a powerful, tangible source of hope in an otherwise grim world.
title: Cate Blanchett: In praise of the humble seed
